content.description:
Absolutely awesome long double crack with beautiful rock. Hampered by a few loose blocks including one that wiggles when you are forced to jam on both sides of it. Would be 4 stars if someone cleans a few of those blocks.

The crack on the right is generally BD #3-#6 size while the splitter on the left is .2-.75.

Being able to use both of these cracks for climbing and protection keeps the climbing moderate and very fun.
content.protection: Doubles of .2 - 6 with quads of #3 should sew it up using both cracks. Bring many runners if you plan to place gear in both cracks. 80m rope just works!
content.location: Starts in a left facing corner up on a pedestal on the left side of the wall, stays shady till about 2 pm. Has a plaque.

content.description: Crispy offset finger crack opens to tight hands at a large block. Pull into a corner and climb a short fun section of fists to OW. Crux is the offset fingers. The OW is mellow and enjoyable.
content.protection: BD: 0.5 - 5. Bolted anchor with new cordage on 03/2019.
content.location: South-facing wall of Pods Wall. Couple hundred feet right of the prominent low roof. Located on a landing above the trail. Look for a clean splitter that hooks right and leads into an offwidth. Scramble choss to the ledge to start.

content.description:
Surely the greatest unnamed 5.11 and one of the top routes at The Creek period.

From the ground it looks good but hardly special, appears to be a generically good left facing corner. However, once you get on it, you'll discover it climbs like an absolute dream and the rock is amazing!

Start with an awkward mantle from a sloping vegetated belay stance. Continue up a left facing corner that tightens down from #3 to .5 but has great feet just when you need them. Bust out an overhanging crux at the top and a few more hero finger jams to the anchor (2 new bolts with rings).
content.protection:
BD camalots:

1x: #4 (for start)

2x: #.3-.5 and #2-3

3x or 4x:  #.75-1

70m rope just works!
content.location: Pretty far left on the Pods Wall

content.description: Handcrack in a black varnished right-facing corner. Funky start: try tunneling! We were too big and had to climb on the outside. A nice stretch of hands leads to an undulating section of thin hands with fun stemming. Crux is pulling a section of tips before the anchor.
content.protection: BD: Red C3 to #3. Anchor is an old fixed hex and a bolt. The tat equalizing them looked good as of 03/2019. Recommend rapping to prevent the rope from getting stuck in the tips corner on the pull.
content.location: Pods Wall has a west-facing side and a south-facing side. There's a prominent low roof on the south-facing side near the apex of the wall. This route is a few hundred feet right of that roof.

content.description: Off fingers to tight hands to a funky pod then ledge. Finishes with steep tight hands.
content.location: just left of the prow, on face to right of large corner

content.description:
Beautiful corner, to 20’ foot hands roof.

It Gone! RIP

In 2019 the pillar had shifted once already and the roof was #4 and #5. Where it had been no larger then #2s.

2021, gone

Watch out for Slot Machine, it’s next!
content.location: In between Pods and Res wall

content.description:
A laser-cut, right-facing, off-fingers, lay-back crack!

Climb delicately past some loose pillars to a stem rest at the base of the laser cut right-facing corner. Starts as fingers and quickly opens to baggy/off-fingers, and then necks back down to fingers right at the anchors.

A beautiful feature on bullet rock with a nice clean edge.
content.protection: BD 0.4-0.75. Mostly 0.5 and 0.75. Red Metolius came in handy before the last punch to the anchor where you're looking at baggy 0.5 and tight 0.75. Two Metolius rap bolts for anchors.
content.location: Pods Wall is spread out. This route is located on the far right side of the crag on the south-facing side of the wall.

content.description:
There was a major rock fall in this area around '05-'06 that was visible from the road, and I thought this climb had been erased. But I hiked up to it this fall and much to my surprise, it's still there!

Located in the big inside bend R of Reservoir Wall, L side of Pods Wall. You will see a splitter going up into a flare and exiting the flare to a big hands splitter.

The start looks dubious but it's not too bad. Climb up some easy chossy ground R of the splitter, get a high piece and move L to a flare with a thin crack. Exit this flare to splitter big fingers going through the sizes to thin hands. Then the flare to big hand splitter mentioned above.

If you can overlook the chossy start and overall dirtiness, this is a decent pitch. One thing to recommend it is that it lives in a sun collector/wind block, similar to the Johnny Cat area. An even more compelling reason to climb it is that it tops out the cliff and is an excellent approach to climb The Cat (the cap rock tower on top of the Reservoir Wall). If you go to climb The Cat, there are two routes. They're both on the front, tall side of The Cat. The left route is a L facing corner, Cat on a Hot Tin Roof. FA Alan the Brit (Heavy Duty) & Brent Obinger. The right hand route is a R facing corner, Rudy's Corner. FA Renan Ozturk & Ivan Cross. These climbs went up simultaneously. There were 8 other people and 6 hulahoops on the summit of The Cat for the FA.

If you go to climb Ham on Rye or The Cat, plan on bringing new webbing for the anchors. Ham on Rye is named after a Bukowski book.
content.protection: tips or smaller through big hands. A 70m rope does not quite reach.
content.location: Right end of Res Wall/ Left side of Pods Wall.

content.description: Start in a right facing corner/flare with hands to the roof, exiting the roof the crack turns straight in and doglegs to the right where the crack pinches down fingers before clipping the chains.
content.protection: In BD Camelot's: .4, (2x) .5 - 3.   Extra 1,2, & 3 would allow you sew it up.
content.location: On the same bench and just to the right of Thank God for Pods.
